{{Infobox language |name=Tol |altname=(Eastern) Jicaque, Jicaque de la Flor |nativename=Tolpan |region=[[Honduras]] |ethnicity={{sigfig|19,600|3}} [[Tolupan people|Tolupan]] (1990)<ref>{{e18|jic|Tol}}</ref> |speakers=almost 500 |date=2012 |ref=<ref>Haurholm-Larsen, Steffen. 2012. [https://www.academia.edu/1818616/_A_qui%C3%A9n_le_importa_Una_encuesta_socioling%C3%BC%C3%ADstica_de_la_lengua_tol_jicaque_de_Honduras ¿A quién le importa? Una encuesta sociolingüística de la lengua tol o jicaque de Honduras.] Talk given at 54th Congress of Americanists. Vienna.</ref> |familycolor=American |fam1=[[Hokan languages|Hokan]] ? |fam2=[[Jicaquean languages|Jicaquean]] |iso3=jic |glotto = toll1241 |glottorefname=Tol }}
'''Tol''', also known as '''Eastern Jicaque''', ''Tolupan'', and ''Torupan'', is spoken by approximately 500 [[Tolupan people]] in [[La Montaña de la Flor]] reservation in [[Morazán Department]], [[Honduras]].{{fact|date=June 2015}}{{huh|reason=Morazán Department is actually in El Salvador|date=June 2015}}
==Name== Tol speakers refer to themselves as the Tolpán, but are called Jicaques or Turrupanes by [[Ladino people|ladinos]].
==Former extent== Tol was also spoken in much of [[Yoro Department]], but only a few speakers were reported in the [[Yoro Valley]] in 1974.
Tol used to be spoken from the [[Río Ulúa]] in the west, to modern-day [[Trujillo, Honduras|Trujillo]] in the east, and to the [[Río Sulaco]] in the inland south. This area included the areas around modern-day [[El Progreso]], [[La Ceiba]], and possibly also [[San Pedro Sula]]. Most Tolupan had fled the Spanish from coastal regions by the early 1800s. The Tol speakers at La Montaña de la Flor fled the Yoro Valley in 1865 to avoid being conscripted into forced labor by the local governor (Campbell & Oltrogge 1980:206, Hagen 1943, Chapman 1978).
==Phonology==
=== Consonants === {| class="wikitable IPA" style=text-align:center ! colspan="2" | ![[Bilabial consonant|Bilabial]] ![[Alveolar consonant|Alveolar]] ![[Lateral consonant|Lateral]] ![[Palatal consonant|Palatal]] ![[Velar consonant|Velar]] ![[Glottal consonant|Glottal]] |- align="center" ! rowspan="3" |[[Stop consonant|Plosive]] !<small>plain</small> |p |t | | |k |ʔ |- align="center" !<small>aspirated</small> |pʰ |tʰ | | |kʰ | |- !<small>ejective</small> |pʼ |tʼ | | |kʼ | |- ! rowspan="3" |[[Affricate consonant|Affricate]] !<small>plain</small> | |t͡s | | | | |- !<small>aspirated</small> | |t͡sʰ | | | | |- !<small>ejective</small> | |t͡sʼ | | | | |- align="center" ! colspan="2" |[[Fricative consonant|Fricative]] |β |s | | | |h |- align="center" ! colspan="2" |[[Nasal consonant|Nasal]] |m |n | | |ŋ | |- align="center" ! colspan="2" |[[Approximant consonant|Approximant]] |w | |l |j, j̈ | | |}
=== Vowels === {| class="wikitable" style=text-align:center ! ![[Front vowel|Front]] ![[Central vowel|Central]] ![[Back vowel|Back]] |- align="center" ![[Close vowel|Close]] |i |ɨ |u |- align="center" ![[Mid vowel|Mid]] |e | |o |- align="center" ![[Open vowel|Open]] | |a | |} <ref>{{Cite book|title=International Journal of American Linguistics Vol. 43, No. 2|last=Ilah Fleming|first=Ronald K. Dennis|publisher=|year=1977|isbn=|location=|pages=121-127}}</ref>
== Grammar ==
=== Constituent order ===
The basic constituent order of Tol is SOV and the language displays a consistently head final order of constituents, i.e. verbs follow the subject and the object, prepositions follow the nouns they refer to, and subordinating conjunctions appear at the end of subordinate clauses.
=== Inflection ===
Verbs and nouns are inflected for person, number and, in the case of verbs, tense, using a number of different morpho-syntactic means which often conflate various meanings (polyexponentiality). These means include, prefixing, suffixing and infixing, ablaut and stress shift and the use of independent pronouns. Tense is also expressed by the use of particles. Number is only marked in noun phrases with animate referents. Some examples are given below.
m-wayúm 'my husband' w-y-ayúm 'your husband' woyúm 'her husband' khis wayúm 'our husband' his wayúm 'your husband' his wayúm 'their husband'
naph üsü müʔüs 'I am drinking water' hiph üsü müs 'you are drinking water' huph üsü mü 'he is drinking water' kuph üsü miskhékh 'we are drinking water' nun üsü müskhé 'you are drinking water' yuph üsü miʔün 'they are drinking water'
Most nouns take one of three suffixes: -(sV)s -(V)N -(V)kh
Examples are
wa/ wo-sís 'house' sith / sith-ím 'avocado' khan / khon-íkh 'bed'
Nouns that never take suffixes refer to body parts and kinship terms.
==References== {{reflist}} * Campbell, Lyle, and David Oltrogge (1980). "Proto-Tol (Jicaque)." ''International Journal of American Linguistics'', 46:205-223 * Dennis, Ronald K. (1976). "La lengua tol (jicaque): los sustantivos." ''Yaxkin'' 1(3): 2-7. * Fleming, Ilah. (1977). "Tol (Jicaque) phonology." ''International Journal of American Linguistics'' 43(2): 121-127. * Holt, Dennis. (1999). ''Tol (Jicaque)''. Languages of the World/Materials 170. Munich: LincomEuropa.

{{multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=November 2009}} {{more footnotes|date=May 2015}} }} {{IPA notice}} This article deals with the [[phonology]] of the standard [[Ukrainian language]]. == Vowels == [[File:Ukrainian vowel chart.svg|thumb|upright=1.13|Ukrainian vowel chart, from {{Harvcoltxt|Pompino-Marschall|Steriopolo|Żygis|2016|p=?}}]] Ukrainian has six vowel [[phoneme]]s: {{IPA|/{{IPA link|i}}, {{IPA link|u}}, {{IPA link|ɪ}}, {{IPA link|ɛ}}, {{IPA link|ɔ}}, {{IPA link|ɑ}}/}}. {{IPA|/ɪ/}} may be classified as a retracted high-mid front vowel,{{Harvcoltxt|Rusanivs’kyj|Taranenko|Zjabljuk|2004|p=104}} transcribed in narrow IPA as {{IPA|[e̠]}}, {{IPA|[ë]}}, {{IPA|[ɪ̞]}} or {{IPA|[ɘ̟]}}. {| class="wikitable" ! ! Front ! Central ! Back |- ! [[Near-close vowel|Close]] | {{IPA link|i}} | {{IPA link|ɪ}} | {{IPA link|u}} |- ! [[Mid vowel|Mid]] | {{IPA link|ɛ}} | | {{IPA link|o̞|ɔ}} |- ! [[Open vowel|Open]] | | {{IPA link|ɑ}} | |} Ukrainian has no phonemic distinction between long and short vowels; however, unstressed vowels are somewhat reduced in time and, as a result, in quality.{{Harvcoltxt|Rusanivs’kyj|Taranenko|Zjabljuk|2004|p=407}} * In unstressed position {{IPA|/ɑ/}} has an allophone {{IPAblink|ɐ}}.{{Harvcoltxt|Buk|Mačutek|Rovenchak|2008|=3}} * Unstressed {{IPA|/ɔ/}} has an allophone {{IPAblink|o}} that slightly approaches {{IPA|/u/}} if it is followed by a syllable with {{IPA|/u/}} or {{IPA|/i/}}. * Unstressed {{IPA|/u/}} has an allophone {{IPAblink|ʊ}}. * Unstressed {{IPA|/ɛ/}} and {{IPA|/ɪ/}} approach {{IPAblink|e}} that may or may not be a common allophone for the two phonemes. * {{IPA|/i/}} has no notable variation in unstressed position. {{clear}} == Consonants == {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" ! rowspan="2" | ! rowspan="2" | [[Labial consonant|Labial]] ! colspan="2" | [[Dental consonant|Dental]]/[[Alveolar consonant|Alveolar]] ! rowspan="2" | [[Postalveolar consonant|Post-
alveolar]] ! rowspan="2" | [[Palatal consonant|Palatal]] ! rowspan="2" | [[Velar consonant|Velar]] ! rowspan="2" | [[Glottal consonant|Glottal]] |- ! Hard ! Soft |- ! [[Nasal stop|Nasal]] | {{IPA link|m}} | {{IPA link|n̪|n}} | {{IPA|nʲ}} | | | | |- ! [[Stop consonant|Stop]] | {{IPA link|p}} {{IPA link|b}} | {{IPA link|t̪|t}} {{IPA link|d̪|d}} | {{IPA|tʲ}} {{IPA|dʲ}} | | | {{IPA link|k}} {{IPA link|ɡ}} | |- ! [[Affricate consonant|Affricate]] | | {{IPA link|t̪͡s̪|t͡s}} {{IPA link|d̪͡z̪|d͡z}} | {{IPA|t͡sʲ}} {{IPA|d͡zʲ}} | {{IPA link|t͡ʃ}} {{IPA link|d͡ʒ}} | | | |- ! [[Fricative consonant|Fricative]] | {{IPA link|f}} | {{IPA link|s̪|s}} {{IPA link|z̪|z}} | {{IPA|sʲ}} {{IPA|zʲ}} | {{IPA link|ʃ}} {{IPA link|ʒ}} | | {{IPA link|x}} |{{IPA link|ɦ|ɦ}} |- ! [[Approximant consonant|Approximant]] |{{IPA link|β̞|w}} |{{IPA link|l}} |{{IPA|lʲ}} | |{{IPA link|j}} | | |- ! [[Trill consonant|Trill]] | |{{IPA link|r}} |{{IPA|rʲ}} | | | | |} In the table above, if there are two consonants in a row, the one to the right is voiced, and the one to the left is voiceless. Phonetic details: * There is no complete agreement about the phonetic nature of {{IPA|/ɦ/}}. According to some linguists, it is pharyngeal {{IPAblink|ʕ}}{{Harvcoltxt|Danyenko|Vakulenko|1995|p=12}} ({{IPAblink|ħ}} [or sometimes {{IPAblink|x}} in weak positions] when devoiced). According to others, it is glottal {{IPAblink|ɦ}}.{{Harvcoltxt|Pugh|Press|2005|p=23}}The sound is described as "laryngeal fricative consonant" ({{lang|uk|гортанний щілинний приголосний}}) in the official orthography: '§ 14. Letter H' in Український правопис, Kyiv: Naukova dumka, 2012, p. 19 ([http://izbornyk.org.ua/pravopys/rozdil1.htm#par14 see e-text])Українська мова: енциклопедія, Kyiv, 2000, p. 85. * Word-finally, {{IPA|/m/}}, {{IPA|/l/}}, {{IPA|/r/}} are voiceless {{IPAblink|m̥}}, {{IPAblink|l̥}}, {{IPAblink|r̥}} after voiceless consonants.{{Harvcoltxt|Danyenko|Vakulenko|1995|pp=6, 8}} In case of {{IPA|/r/}}, it only happens after {{IPA|/t/}}.{{Harvcoltxt|Danyenko|Vakulenko|1995|p=8}} * {{IPA|/w/}} is most commonly bilabial {{IPAblink|β̞}} before vowels but can alternate with labiodental {{IPAblink|ʋ}} (most commonly before {{IPA|/i/}}),{{Harvcoltxt|Žovtobrjux|Kulyk|1965|pp=121–122}} and can be a true labiovelar {{IPAblink|w}} before {{IPA|/ɔ/}} or {{IPA|/u/}}. It is also vocalized to {{IPA|[u̯]}} before a consonant at the beginning of a word, after a vowel before a consonant or after a vowel at the end of a word.{{Harvcoltxt|Rusanivs’kyj|Taranenko|Zjabljuk|2004|pp=522–523}} If {{IPA|/w/}} occurs before a voiceless consonant and not after a vowel, the voiceless articulation {{IPAblink|ʍ}} is also possible. * {{IPA|/r/}} often becomes a single tap {{IPAblink|ɾ}} in the spoken language. * {{IPA|/t, d, dʲ, n, nʲ, s, sʲ, z, zʲ, t͡s, t͡sʲ, d͡z, d͡zʲ/}} are dental {{IPA|[{{IPAlink|t̪}}, {{IPAlink|d̪}}, {{IPA|d̪ʲ}}, {{IPAlink|n̪}}, {{IPA|n̪ʲ}}, {{IPAlink|s̪}}, {{IPA|s̪ʲ}}, {{IPAlink|z̪}}, {{IPA|z̪ʲ}}, {{IPAlink|t̪͡s̪}}, {{IPA|t̪͡s̪ʲ}}, {{IPAlink|d̪͡z̪}}, {{IPA|d̪͡z̪ʲ}}]}},{{Harvcoltxt|Danyenko|Vakulenko|1995|pp=8–10}} while {{IPA|/tʲ, l, lʲ, r, rʲ/}} are alveolar {{IPA|[{{IPA|tʲ}}, {{IPAlink|l}}, {{IPA|lʲ}}, {{IPAlink|r}}, {{IPA|rʲ}}]}}.{{Harvcoltxt|Danyenko|Vakulenko|1995|pp=8 and 10}} * The group of palatalized consonants consists of 10 phonemes: {{IPA|/j, dʲ, zʲ, lʲ, nʲ, rʲ, sʲ, tʲ, t͡sʲ, d͡zʲ/}}. All except {{IPA|/j/}} have a soft and a hard variant. There is no agreement about the nature of the palatalization of {{IPA|/rʲ/}}; sometimes, it is considered as a semi-palatalized{{clarify|date=September 2017}} consonant.{{Harvcoltxt|Ponomariv|2001|pp=16, 20}} Labial consonants {{IPA|/p, b, m, f/}} have just semi-palatalized versions, and {{IPA|/w/}} has only the hard variant.{{Harvcoltxt|Ponomariv|2001|pp=14-15}} The palatalization of the consonants {{IPA|/ɦ, ɡ, ʒ, k, x, t͡ʃ, ʃ, d͡ʒ/}} is weak; they are usually treated rather as the allophones of the respective hard consonants, not as separate phonemes.{{Harvcoltxt|Buk|Mačutek|Rovenchak|2008|=4}} * Unlike Russian and several other Slavic languages, Ukrainian does not have [[final-obstruent devoicing|final devoicing]] for most [[obstruent consonant|obstruent]]s, as can be seen, for example, in {{wikt-lang|uk|віз}} "cart", which is pronounced {{audio-IPA|Uk-віз.ogg|[ˈʋiz]}}, not {{IPA|*[ˈʋis]}}. * The fricative articulations {{IPA|[{{IPAlink|v}}, {{IPAlink|ɣ}}]}} are voiced allophones of {{IPA|/f, x/}} respectively if they are voiced before other voiced consonants. (See [[#Consonant assimilation]].) {{IPA|/x, ɦ/}} do not form a perfect voiceless-voiced phoneme pair, but their allophones may overlap if {{IPA|/ɦ/}} is devoiced to {{IPA|[x]}} (rather than {{IPA|[h]}}). In the standard language, {{IPA|/f, w/}} do not form a voiceless-voiced phoneme pair at all, as {{IPA|[v]}} does not phonemically overlap with {{IPA|/w/}}, and {{IPA|[ʍ]}} (voiceless allophone of {{IPA|/w/}}) does not phonemically overlap with {{IPA|/f/}}. When two or more consonants occur word-finally, a vowel is [[Epenthesis|epenthesized]] under the following conditions:{{Harvcoltxt|Carlton|1972|p=?}} Given a consonantal grouping C1({{lang|uk|ь}})C2({{lang|uk|ь}}), C being any consonant. The vowel is inserted between the two consonants and after the {{lang|uk|ь}}. A vowel is not inserted unless C2 is either {{IPA|/k/}}, {{IPA|/w/}}, {{IPA|/l/}}, {{IPA|/m/}}, {{IPA|/r/}}, or {{IPA|/ts/}}. Then: # If C1 is {{IPA|/w/}}, {{IPA|/ɦ/}}, {{IPA|/k/}}, or {{IPA|/x/}}, the epenthisized vowel is always {{IPA|[o]}} ## No vowel is epenthesized if the {{IPA|/w/}} is derived from a Common Slavic vocalic *l, for example, {{IPA|/wɔwk/}} (see below) # If C2 is {{IPA|/l/}}, {{IPA|/m/}}, {{IPA|/r/}}, or {{IPA|/ts/}}, then the vowel is {{IPA|/ɛ/}}. # The combinations, {{IPA|/-stw/}} {{IPA|/-sk/}} are not broken up. # If the C1 is {{IPA|/j/}} ({{lang|uk|й}}), the above rules may apply. However, both forms (with and without the fill vowel) often exist. ===Alternation of vowels and semivowels=== Ukrainian also has a non-syllabic {{IPA|[u̯]}}, as an allophone of {{IPA|/w/}}. The semivowels {{IPA|/j/}} and {{IPA|/w/}} alternate with the vowels {{IPA|/i/}} and {{IPA|/u/}} respectively. The semivowels are used in syllable codas: after a vowel and before a consonant, either within a word or between words:{{citation needed|date=November 2009}} : {{lang|uk|він '''і'''де́}} {{IPA|/ˈwin '''i'''ˈdɛ/}} ('he's coming') : {{lang|uk|вона́ '''й'''де}} {{IPA|/wɔˈnɑ ˈ'''j'''dɛ/}} ('she's coming') : {{lang|uk|він '''і''' вона́}} {{IPA|/ˈwin '''i''' wɔˈnɑ/}} ('he and she') : {{lang|uk|вона́ '''й''' він}} {{IPA|/wɔˈnɑ '''j''' ˈwin/}} ('she and he'); : {{lang|uk|'''У'''томи́вся '''в'''же}} {{IPA|/'''u'''tɔˈmɪwsʲɑ ˈ'''w'''ʒɛ/}} ('already gotten tired') : {{lang|uk|'''У'''же́ '''в'''томи́вся}} {{IPA|/'''u'''ˈʒɛ '''w'''tɔˈmɪwsʲɑ/}} ('already gotten tired') : {{lang|uk|Він '''у'''томи́вся.}} {{IPA|/ˈwin '''u'''tɔmɪwsʲɑ/}} ('He's gotten tired.') : {{lang|uk|Він '''у''' ха́ті.}} {{IPA|/ˈwin '''u''' ˈxɑtʲi/}} ('He's inside the house.') : {{lang|uk|Вона́ '''в''' ха́ті.}} {{IPA|/wɔˈnɑ '''w''' ˈxɑtʲi/}} ('She's inside the house.') : {{lang|uk|під'''у'''чи́ти}} {{IPA|/pid'''u'''ˈt͡ʃɪtɪ/}} ('to learn/teach (a little more)') : {{lang|uk|ви'''в'''чи́ти}} {{IPA|/wɪ'''w'''ˈt͡ʃɪtɪ/}} ('to have learnt') That feature distinguishes Ukrainian phonology remarkably from Russian and Polish, two related languages with many cognates. === Consonant assimilation === Voiceless obstruents are voiced when preceding voiced ones, but the reverse is not true:{{Harvcoltxt|Mascaró|Wetzels|2001|p=209}} * {{wikt-lang|uk|наш}} {{IPA|[nɑʃ]}} ('our') * {{lang|uk|наш дід}} {{IPA|[nɑʒ ˈdʲid]}} ('our grandfather') * {{wikt-lang|uk|бере́за}} {{IPA|[bɛˈrɛzɑ]}} ('birch') * {{wikt-lang|uk|бері́зка}} {{IPA|[bɛˈrʲizkɑ]}} ('small birch') The exceptions are {{lang|uk|легко}}, {{lang|uk|вогко}}, {{lang|uk|нігті}}, {{lang|uk|кігті}}, {{lang|uk|дьогтю}}, {{lang|uk|дігтяр}}, and derivatives: {{IPA|/ɦ/}} may then be devoiced to {{IPAblink|h}} or even merge with {{IPA|/x/}}. Unpalatalized dental consonants {{IPA|/n, t, d, t͡s, d͡z, s, z, r, l/}} become palatalized if they are followed by other palatalized dental consonants {{IPA|/nʲ, tʲ, dʲ, t͡sʲ, d͡zʲ, sʲ, zʲ, rʲ, lʲ/}}. They are also typically palatalized before the vowel {{IPA|/i/}}. Historically, contrasting unpalatalized and palatalized articulations of consonants before {{IPA|/i/}} were possible and more common, with the absence of palatalization usually reflecting that regular sound changes in the language made an {{IPA|/i/}} vowel actually evolve from an older, non-palatalizing {{IPA|/ɔ/}} vowel. [[Ukrainian grammar]] still allows for {{IPA|/i/}} to alternate with either {{IPA|/ɛ/}} or {{IPA|/ɔ/}} in the regular inflection of certain words. The absence of consonant palatalization before {{IPA|/i/}} has become rare, however, but is still allowed. While the labial consonants {{IPA|/m, p, b, f, w/}} cannot be phonemically palatalized, they can still precede one of the iotating vowels {{lang|uk|є і ьо ю я}}, when many speakers replace the would-be sequences {{IPA|*{{!}}mʲ, pʲ, bʲ, fʲ, wʲ{{!}}}} with the consonant clusters {{IPA|/mj, pj, bj, fj, wj/}}, a habit also common in nearby Polish. The separation of labial consonant from {{IPA|/j/}} is already hard-coded in many Ukrainian words (and written as such with an apostrophe), such as in {{lang|uk|В'ячеслав}} {{IPA|/wjɑt͡ʃɛˈslɑw/}} "[[Vyacheslav]]", {{wikt-lang|uk|ім'я}} {{IPA|/iˈmjɑ/}} "name" and {{wikt-lang|uk|п'ять}} {{IPA|/pjɑtʲ/}} "five".{{cn|date=September 2017}} Dental sibilant consonants {{IPA|/t͡s, d͡z, s, z/}} become palatalized before any of the labial consonants {{IPA|/m, p, b, f, w/}} followed by one of the iotating vowels {{lang|uk|є і ьо ю я}}, but the labial consonants themselves cannot retain phonemic palatalization. Thus, words like {{lang|uk|свят}} {{IPA|/sʲw(j)ɑt/}} "holiday" and {{lang|uk|сват}} {{IPA|/swɑt/}} "matchmaker" retain their separate pronunciations (whether or not an actual {{IPA|/j/}} is articulated). Sibilant consonants (including affricates) in clusters assimilate with the place of articulation and palatalization state of the last segment in a cluster. The most common case of such assimilation is the verbal ending {{lang|uk|-шся}} in which {{IPA|{{!}}ʃsʲɑ{{!}}}} assimilates into {{IPA|/sʲːɑ/}}. Dental plosives {{IPA|/t, tʲ, d, dʲ/}} assimilate to affricate articulations before coronal affricates or fricatives {{IPA|/t͡s, d͡z, s, z, t͡sʲ, d͡zʲ, sʲ, zʲ, t͡ʃ, d͡ʒ, ʃ, ʒ/}} and assume the latter consonant's place of articulation and palatalization. If the sequences {{IPA|{{!}}t.t͡s, d.d͡z, t.t͡sʲ, d.d͡zʲ, t.t͡ʃ, d.d͡ʒ{{!}}}} regressively assimilate to {{IPA|/t͡s.t͡s, d͡z.d͡z, t͡sʲ.t͡sʲ, d͡zʲ.d͡zʲ, t͡ʃ.t͡ʃ, d͡ʒ.d͡ʒ/}}, they gain geminate articulations {{IPA|[t͡sː d͡zː t͡sʲː d͡zʲː t͡ʃː d͡ʒː]}}. == Deviations of spoken language == There are some typical deviations which may appear in spoken language (often under the influence of [[Russian language|Russian]]);[http://ponomariv-kultura-slova.wikidot.com/fonetyka Oleksandr Ponomariv. Культура слова: мовностилістичні поради] usually they are considered as phonetic errors by linguists.[http://journlib.univ.kiev.ua/index.php?act=article&article=1481 Vitalij Marhalyk. Проблеми орфоепії в молодіжних телепрограмах] * {{IPAblink|ɨ}} for {{IPAslink|ɪ}} * {{IPAblink|t͡ɕ}} for {{IPAslink|t͡ʃ}} and {{IPA|[ɕt͡ɕ]}} or even {{IPAblink|ɕː}} for {{IPA|[ʃt͡ʃ]}} * {{IPA|[rʲ]}} for {{IPA|/r/}}, {{IPA|[bʲ]}} for {{IPA|/b/}}, {{IPA|[vʲ]}} for {{IPA|/w/}} ({{lang|uk|Ха́'''р'''ків}}, {{lang|uk|О'''б'''}}, {{lang|uk|любо́'''в'''ю}}) * {{IPA|[v]}} or {{IPA|[f]}} (the latter in syllable-final position) for {{IPA|[w ~ u̯ ~ β̞ ~ ʋ ~ ʍ]}} ({{lang|uk|любо́'''в'''}}, {{lang|uk|роби́'''в'''}}, {{lang|uk|'''в'''ари́ти}}, {{lang|uk|'''в'''ода́}}), in effect also turning {{IPA|/f, w/}} into a true voiceless-voiced phoneme pair, which is not the case in the standard language * [[Final-obstruent devoicing]] == Historical phonology == {{main article|Proto-Slavic language}} Modern standard Ukrainian descends from [[Proto-Slavic|Common Slavic]] and is characterized by a number of [[sound change]]s and morphological developments, many of which are shared with other [[East Slavic languages]]. These include: # In a newly closed [[syllable]], that is, a syllable that ends in a [[consonant]], Common Slavic *o and *e mutated into *i if the following [[vowel]] was one of the [[yer]]s (*ŭ or *ĭ).{{citation needed|date=November 2009}} # [[Pleophony]]: The Common Slavic combinations, *CoRC and *CeRC, where R is either *r or *l, become in Ukrainian: ## CorC gives ''CoroC'' (Common Slavic *borda gives Ukrainian ''boroda'', {{wikt-lang|uk|борода́}}) ## ColC gives ''ColoC'' (Common Slavic *bolto gives Ukrainian ''boloto'', {{wikt-lang|uk|боло́то}}) ## CerC gives ''CereC'' (Common Slavic *berza gives Ukrainian ''bereza'', {{wikt-lang|uk|бере́за}}) ## CelC gives ''ColoC'' (Common Slavic *melko gives Ukrainian ''moloko'', {{wikt-lang|uk|молоко́}}) # The Common Slavic nasal vowel *ę is reflected as {{IPA|/jä/}}; a preceding [[labial consonant]] generally was not palatalized after this, and after a [[postalveolar consonant|postalveolar]] it became {{IPA|/ä/}}. Examples: Common Slavic *pętĭ became Ukrainian {{IPA|/pjätʲ/}} ({{wikt-lang|uk|п'ять|п’ять}}); Common Slavic *telę became Ukrainian {{IPA|[tɛˈlʲæ]}} ({{wikt-lang|uk|теля́}}); and Common Slavic *kurĭčę became Ukrainian {{IPA|/kurˈt͡ʃä/}} ({{lang|uk|курча́}}).{{citation needed|date=November 2009}} # Common Slavic *ě (Cyrillic ѣ), generally became Ukrainian {{IPA|/i/}} except:{{citation needed|date=November 2009}} ## word-initially, where it became {{IPA|/ji/}}: Common Slavic *(j)ěsti became Ukrainian {{wikt-lang|uk|ї́сти}} {{IPA|/ˈjistɪ/}} ## after the postalveolar sibilants where it became {{IPA|/ä/}}: Common Slavic *ležěti became Ukrainian {{IPA|/lɛˈʒätɪ/}} ({{lang|uk|лежа́ти}}) # Common Slavic *i and *y are both reflected in Ukrainian as {{IPA|/ɪ/}}{{citation needed|date=November 2009}} # The Common Slavic combination -CĭjV, where V is any vowel, became {{IPA|-CʲːV}}, except:{{citation needed|date=November 2009}} ## if C is labial or {{IPA|/r/}} where it became -CjV ## if V is the Common Slavic *e, then the vowel in Ukrainian mutated to {{IPA|/ä/}}, e.g., Common Slavic *žitĭje became Ukrainian {{IPA|[ʒɪtʲːæ]}} ({{lang|uk|життя́}}) ## if V is Common Slavic *ĭ, then the combination became {{IPA|/ɛj/}}, e.g., genitive plural in Common Slavic *myšĭjĭ became Ukrainian {{IPA|/mɪ̞ˈʃɛj/}} ({{lang|uk|мише́й}}) ## if one or more consonants precede C then there is no doubling of the consonants in Ukrainian # Sometime around the early thirteenth century, the [[voiced velar stop]] lenited to {{IPA|[ɣ]}} (except in the cluster *zg).{{Harvcoltxt|Shevelov|1977|p=145}} Within a century, {{IPA|/ɡ/}} was reintroduced from Western European loanwords and, around the sixteenth century, {{IPA|[ɣ]}} [[debuccalization|debuccalized]] to {{IPA|[ɦ]}}.{{Harvcoltxt|Shevelov|1977|p=148}} # Common Slavic combinations *dl and *tl were simplified to {{IPA|/l/}}, for example, Common Slavic *mydlo became Ukrainian {{IPA|/ˈmɪlɔ/}} ({{wikt-lang|uk|ми́ло}}).{{citation needed|date=November 2009}} # Common Slavic *ǔl and *ĭl became {{IPA|/ɔw/}}. For example, Common Slavic *vĭlkǔ became {{IPA|/wɔwk/}} ({{wikt-lang|uk|вовк}}) in Ukrainian.{{citation needed|date=November 2009}} == Notes == {{reflist|30em}} == References == {{refbegin|30em}} * {{citation |last=Bilous |first=Tonia |year=2005 |format=DOC |title=Українська мова засобами Міжнародного фонетичного алфавіту |trans-title=Ukrainian in International Phonetic alphabet |url=http://ruthenia.info/txt/rusa/UkrIPA.doc }} * {{citation |last1=Buk |first1=Solomija |last2=Mačutek |first2=Ján |last3=Rovenchak |first3=Andrij |year=2008 |title=Some properties of the Ukrainian writing system |arxiv=0802.4198 |bibcode=2008arXiv0802.4198B }} * {{citation |last=Carlton |first=T.R. |year=1972 |title=A Guide to the Declension of Nouns in Ukrainian |place=Edmonton, Alberta |publisher=University of Alberta Press }} * {{citation |last1=Danyenko |first1=Andrii |last2=Vakulenko |first2=Serhii |year=1995 |title=Ukrainian |publisher=Lincom Europa |isbn=978-3-929075-08-3 |url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Ukrainian.html?id=WUsbAQAAIAAJ&redir_esc=y }} * {{Cite journal |last1=Mascaró |first1=Joan |last2=Wetzels |first2=W. '''Wiio's laws''' are ''humoristically'' formulated observations about how [[human communication|humans communicate]].
Wiio's laws are usually commonly with "Human communications usually fail except by accident", which is the main observation made by Professor [[Osmo Antero Wiio]] in 1978.<ref>{{cite book|title=Wiion lait - ja vähän muidenkin (Wiio's laws - and some others) |author=Osmo A. Wiio|isbn=951-35-1657-1|publisher=Weilin+Göös|year=1978}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.cs.tut.fi/~jkorpela/wiio.html |title=A commentary of Wiio's laws |last1=Korpela |first1=Jukka Kalervo |author-link1=:fi:Jukka Korpela (tietokirjailija) |date=2010 |website=IT and communication |access-date=2016-02-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Flauaus |first=Joeyn |url=http://journal.emwa.org/documents/journal/TWS/TWS%202009%204%2018.pdf |title=Principles of communication |journal=The Write Stuff |publisher=European Medical Writers Association |volume=18 |issue=4 |year=2009 |page=246}}</ref>
== The laws == The fundamental Wiio's law states that "Communication usually fails, except by accident". The full set of laws is as follows: # Communication usually fails, except by accident. ## If communication can fail, it will. ## If communication cannot fail, it still most usually fails. ## If communication seems to succeed in the intended way, there's a misunderstanding. ## If you are content with your message, communication certainly fails. # If a message can be interpreted in several ways, it will be interpreted in a manner that maximizes the damage. # There is always someone who knows better than you what you meant with your message. # The more we communicate, the worse communication succeeds. ## The more we communicate, the faster misunderstandings propagate. # In [[mass communication]], the important thing is not how things are but how they seem to be. # The importance of a news item is inversely proportional to the square of the distance. # The more important the situation is, the more probably you forget an essential thing that you remembered a moment ago.
